title: Relentless Attacks on Jerome Powell and Federal Reserve Independence
summary: Trump has repeatedly attacked Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell (whom he appointed) and threatened Fed independence, a cornerstone of economic stability. In 2019, asked 'who is our bigger enemy, Jay Powell or Chairman Xi?' In second term, called Powell 'that jerk,' 'stupid person,' and 'major loser.' DOJ launched criminal investigation of Powell in 2026. Trump threatened to fire Powell (legally cannot), discussed it with GOP lawmakers, showed them draft firing letter. Bipartisan group of economists including former Fed chairs condemned attacks as 'unprecedented attempt to undermine' Fed independence. Experts warn attacks could cause higher inflation, mortgage rates, market volatility.
keyFacts: August 2019: Trump tweeted 'who is our bigger enemy, Jay Powell or Chairman Xi [Jinping]?'
Repeatedly demanded Powell lower interest rates via social media throughout presidency
Called Powell an 'enemy,' 'fool,' 'incompetent,' 'stupid person,' 'that jerk,' 'major loser'
2019: Privately discussed with White House counsel possibility of firing Powell
July 2025: Asked GOP lawmakers if he should fire Powell, showed them draft firing letter
Trump threatened lawsuit against Powell over Fed headquarters renovation costs
January 2026: DOJ launched criminal investigation into Powell
Powell directly connected DOJ probe to Trump's complaints about interest rate decisions
Powell stated when asked if Trump can fire him: 'Not permitted under the law'
Fed Chair can only be removed 'for cause' (serious misconduct) under Federal Reserve Act of 1913
Supreme Court reaffirmed in May 2025 that Trump lacks authority to arbitrarily fire Fed Chair
13 top economists including Bernanke, Greenspan, Yellen condemned attacks on Fed independence
Brett House (Columbia): 'assault on Fed independence' means 'higher rates, greater volatility'
Economists warn attacks could trigger 'severe reaction in markets' and higher mortgage rates
Mark Zandi (Moody's): 'There's nothing but downside here for investors and consumers'
Experts: Most public and aggressive presidential attacks on Fed in modern history
Fed independence established to prevent political manipulation of monetary policy
